awd_titl_txt: Nanostructure Engineering Is Another Approach Toward Membrane-Active Antimicrobials with Desirable Activity and Selectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract # DMR ? 1810767
Non-Technical Summary 

Antibiotic-resistant superbugs that elude one or more traditional antibiotics are causing a public health crisis. Membrane-active antimicrobials represent a new family of promising antibiotic materials to address this crisis. They include a wide variety of small molecules, polymers, polypeptides, self-assembled structures, and organic-inorganic hybrid materials that kill bacteria by disrupting bacterial membranes. Since this mode of damage does not target specific biosynthetic pathways, the possibility of inducing bacterial resistance is greatly reduced. However, most current designs of membrane-active antimicrobials are not ready for applications yet because their hydrophobicity believed to be indispensable for breaking bacterial membranes also damages mammalian cells, which gives rise to their unacceptable toxicity. A critical but poorly understood question is how to design hydrophilic membrane-active antimicrobials that kill bacteria specifically without having to breach the hydrophobic cell membrane in general. Recent discovery of various membrane-active antibiotic nanomaterials suggests that nanostructure engineering could be another approach to develop membrane-active antimicrobials. The objective of this award is to adapt materials engineering, chemistry, and biological tools for the development of hydrophilic nanostructured antibiotic materials, and to elucidate the role of nanostructures on bacterial membrane remodeling. The successful outcomes of this award will pave the way for a potential paradigm shift to develop novel antibiotic materials with desirable activity, selectivity, and biocompatibility to fight bacterial resistance. Integrated with the research activities is a multi-tiered antimicrobial education program that will bring broad societal awareness on antibiotic resistance, and train next generation of scientists on the development of new antibiotic materials. 

Technical Summary

The overall objective of this award is to adapt materials engineering, chemistry, and biological tools for the development of nanostructured membrane-active antibiotic materials (i.e., "nanoantibiotics"), and to elucidate the role of nanostructures on bacterial membrane remodeling. The central hypothesis is that hydrophilic linear-chain polymers that do not breach the hydrophobic membrane interior but have poor antimicrobial activity can be transformed into potent antibiotic materials with high selectivity when assembled into nanostructures. This award will identify the role of multivalent interactions that drive this transformation, elucidate how nanostructure itself helps regulate antimicrobial activity and selectivity, and determine the feasibility of triple selectivity in the design of nanoantibiotics that will disintegrate and become inactive in response to environmental stimuli. This award will help open a door to transform diverse hydrophilic polymers that have excellent biocompatibility but weak antibiotic activity into potent nanostructured antibiotic materials. It will also reveal how to use physical dimensions of nanostructured membrane-active antibiotic materials as a simple tool to tune their activity and selectivity, potentially recruiting the latest development in both the bottom-up and top-down nanostructure engineering into antibiotic designs. Finally, it will examine a prototypical design of nanoantibiotics with dismantling "switch", shedding light on how to turn off antimicrobial activity "on demand" by disassembling antibiotic nanostructures after their service, hence reducing the prolonged presence of residue antibiotics in natural habitats that not only helps bacteria develop resistance, but also adversely impacts the ecosystems. This award will provide abundant training opportunities for postdoc, graduate and undergraduate students, and K12 participants in the interdisciplinary area of biology, chemistry, and materials science and engineering, support educational development on membrane-active antibiotic materials, and promote broad societal awareness on antibiotic resistance and antibiotic materials to diverse participants at all levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Antibiotic resistance is a global public health crisis, and ?one of our most serious health threats? (CDC, 2013). This glooming situation is exacerbated by the lack of new antibiotics in the pipeline, which prompted the White House to issue a national action plan for combating antibiotic-resistant bacteria in 2015, vowing to "accelerate basic and applied research and development for new antibiotics, other therapeutics, and vaccines". Membrane-active antimicrobials (MAAs) have been widely anticipated as the promising candidates of new antibiotics. Decades of research has led to the discovery of thousands of antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) and synthetic mimics of AMPs (SMAMPs), deeper understanding about their modes of action, biodistribution, toxicity, and the effects of molecular details (such as the types of cations, the arrangement of cationic and hydrophobic moieties, etc.) on their activity and selectivity. Notwithstanding the very promising progress, breakthrough in clinical applications of MAAs is still few and far between. Toxicity is one of the biggest barriers that hamper the translation of MAAs from bench side to bedside, of which the indiscriminate hydrophobic interaction that disrupts both bacterial and mammalian membranes is a major contributing factor. 

 

This project addressed the grand challenge of multidrug-resistant bacterial infections via the development of hydrophilic MAAs that target bacteria specifically without having to breach the hydrophobic membrane interior of mammalian cells. It successfully determined the important roles of nanostructure engineering on the design of MAAs, identified the role of multivalent interactions that drive this transformation, elucidated how nanostructure itself regulates antimicrobial activity and selectivity, and demonstrated the proof-of-concept triple selectivity in the design of nanoantibiotics (i.e., selective activity between bacteria and mammalian cells, between different types of bacteria, and between in-clinical use and in-environment waste states). As a result, this study opened a new door to transform diverse hydrophilic polymers that have excellent biocompatibility but weak antibiotic activity into potent nanoantibiotics. No more chemical acrobatics on seeking the elusive cationic-hydrophobic balance is needed. It also revealed the guiding concept of using the physical dimension of nanostructured MAAs as a simple tool to tune their activity and selectivity, hence shedding light to recruit both the bottom-up and top-down nanoengineering strategies into antibiotic designs. Finally, this study demonstrated a prototypical design of nanoantibiotics with a deactivating "switch" that responds to stimuli presented exclusively in natural habitats, which inspires future work on harnessing bioorthogonal chemistry to develop environmentally benign nanoantibiotics. The series of discoveries helped resolve the long-standing dilemma that walks a fine line between the cationic-hydrophobic boundary in the hope of trading toxicity with antimicrobial activity, and paved the way for a potential paradigm shift to develop MAAs with desirable activity, selectivity, and biocompatibility via nanostructure engineering. 

 

Through the integrated research and education, this project provided opportunities to improve educational components for graduate and medical students on membrane biophysics and antimicrobials, as well as to engage K12 and undergraduate students through various campus programs to have ?hands-on? research experience on biomaterials. Specifically, this project provided STEM trainings for 3 postdoc research associates, 2 graduate students, and 3 undergraduate students. Among the trainees 6 are women and 2 are African American, and 2 of the undergraduate students (both African American Women) graduated Magna Cum Laude from the Honors College of Texas Tech University. This study has also resulted in 10 peer-reviewed publications (including 1 Cover Story), 1 US patent, and 13 conference presentations. The research findings derived from this study have been disseminated widely to scientific community and to general public, including Research Highlight by C&EN and Science News by many news media, which promoted broader societal awareness and education on how to mitigate antibiotic resistance through biomedical science understanding and biomaterial engineering.
